entry.title: New Customer Influence Sessions for SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Hi all,

Since the launch of SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC), in February 2025, we have been overwhelmed with the level of customer interest and adoption. As we began the rollout, we have had several feedback programs with customers to help bring them live for the key use cases we seek to enable. We now want to scale this to a broader community of customers through SAP Influence.

We are writing this post to announce 2 things:

  1. We are renaming our existing Data & Analytics sessions to BDC Datasphere and BDC: SAP Analytics Cloud. This move has no impact on investment priorities or the delivery of existing ideas. We are making this change to reflect that these products are now part of SAP Business Data Cloud.
  2. We are bringing onboard new influence communities for BDC Catalog, BDC BW Modernization, BDC: SAP Databricks, BDC Administration, BDC Connect, BDC Intelligent Applications & Data Products.

The changes to existing communities and creation of new communities will happen in the next couple of days. There will also be some movement of ideas between session categories over the next couple of weeks as we implement this new setup. We will update this blog with a link to the new sessions directly after we launch them. We will also add SAP BDC to the central entry point for key influence sessions located here. 

The reason we decided to split SAP BDC into multiple influence sessions is to make it easy for individual users to follow the areas which interest them. Some of these areas are early in their product lifecycle, but they will gain momentum over time and influence will help with this progress. 

We will also use this opportunity to improve our community's responsiveness and communication across all SAP BDC products by reusing the processes that we used for SAP Analytics Cloud in the last couple of years. We cannot deliver all customer requests, but Influence Communities are really useful to understand customer pain points and help identify customers who can deliver feedback on upcoming features. We are always listening and watching.

The BDC session group with its influence communities mentioned above will be owned by the BDC enablement, evangelism and community team under Subha Ramachandran, in Product Management. The influence sessions will be actively managed in partnership with our Product Success teams. I had the privilege to work on the initial strategy and set up the community because of my work on the SAP Analytics Cloud Influence session, which I will continue into the future.

Thanks,
Richard

entry.title: Proactive Monitoring that Integrates Retail Operations in a Data-driven World
entry.content:
Imagine a global retailer preparing for the holiday season, a time when system stability is paramount. In previous years, unexpected disruptions caused delays and customer dissatisfaction. This year, things are different. By implementing proactive monitoring powered by AI and Collective Intelligence, the retailer identified early signals of potential issues weeks before peak demand. This story exemplifies how proactive monitoring transforms support from reactive firefighting to predictive prevention.

Why Proactive Monitoring Matters

Proactive monitoring reduces escalations, improves customer confidence, and optimizes operations. Instead of waiting for incidents to occur, we anticipate them, ensuring uninterrupted business continuity. For example, during the Holiday Season Readiness Program, proactive monitoring helped SAP support teams detect anomalies in critical systems, preventing potential outages for major e-commerce customers.

How It Works

The process begins with comprehensive data collection—telemetry from cloud systems, business process data, and historical case patterns. AI-driven algorithms then analyze these inputs to recognize patterns and correlate events. When anomalies are detected, automated workflows trigger alerts and initiate Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation actions.

Breaking Data Silos

Success depends on breaking down data silos. Only by building a Collective Intelligence framework—where insights from global case data, configuration logs, and usage analytics converge—can this model be scaled across the entire customer base. As data needs to be used collaboratively, data sharing enables an environment where information is accessible in a timely manner.

Benefits

Among the benefits of proactive monitoring, they can range from faster root cause analysis to reduced mean time to resolution. The first refers to the process of identification of causes and reasons for an issue taking place, and the latter concerns the measurement of how quickly a system responds to a failure once it is recognized. Both play a part in refining the customer experience through invisible, but automated support.

With the proactive monitoring strategy anchored in AI, retailers can turn their peak shopping seasons from difficult periods into opportunities for improving customer engagement and operational resilience. A continued adoption of AI-driven capabilities is what will enable smarter planning and sustainable data-driven growth. strategic AI adoption and thoughtful implementation will drive retail excellence in an increasingly digital and data-driven world.

A special thanks to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article.

entry.title: Preliminary What’s New Information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4
entry.content:
Preliminary version of What’s New information and of the Product Assistance are now available for customers and partners to get a preview on the upcoming new and changed features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4.

You can find this preview on the current SAP Help Portal page SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (see What’s New section “Preview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4”). To access the Preliminary What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer or the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool.

The RASD tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The preliminary information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.4 will be available in RASD within the next few days. We recommend using RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you. A valid S-User ID is needed to use the RASD tool and to view all the preliminary content stated above.

For any feedback you may have, try the Commenting Feature for What's New documentation in this release. See this blog for more information.

entry.title: To the Left, To the Left: Setting Businesses Up for Irreplaceable Success
entry.content:
Consider a scenario where a critical update is scheduled for a financial services customer ahead of a major fiscal event. Traditionally, risks would surface post-deployment, leading to costly escalations. That is where a shift to the left walks into the stage: as the testing and detection steps are moved earlier into the lifecycle, an eventual delay in release is avoided, as well as the increase in costs associated with fixings issues. In other words, shifting to left is like reserving the seat in the first rows for testing!

At first glance, it may appear that risks are put in the spotlight, much like nominees at an award show. However, in reality, this approach aims at reducing them. Early recognition of potential issues enables development teams to allocate more time to data cleansing and preparation, tasks that typically consume a significant part of their efforts. This proactive approach allows for more focus on generating valuable insights rather than dealing with escalations.

What Does Shift Left Mean?

Shift Left involves moving risk detection and mitigation earlier in the lifecycle. This approach reduces downstream support costs and enhances customer satisfaction. During the Holiday Season Readiness Program, Shift Left strategies ensured that preventative controls were in place well before peak transaction periods. These strategies included:

  • Implementing Preventive Customer Risk Mitigation workflows for early alerts and automated case creation
  • Integrating with Cloud ALM for lifecycle event monitoring
  • Defining governance models for clear ownership of risk mitigation

Predictive Intelligence

Predictive intelligence uses Collective Intelligence to aggregate insights from global case data and apply AI models for event-to-issue correlation. This enables proactive actions that prevent disruptions before they impact customers.

Breaking Data Silos for Scale

Scaling this model requires dismantling data silos. By pooling insights across teams and regions, we create a unified intelligence network capable of supporting our entire customer base efficiently. With reliable data through the software deployment process, customers can make well-informed decisions at all stages of their businesses, that could lead to better budget management likewise.

Impact

This method is aligned with SAP’s vision for an effortless customer experience. It reduces escalations and downtime while improving operational efficiency. By incorporating recurrent tests at every step of the development process, the system is continuously reviewed and adjusted as needed. Just as filming involves many behind-the-scenes teams, a shift to the left ensures that the backstage engines are aware and constantly prepared for the result that customers witness.

In conclusion, the Shift Left approach changes traditional development and deployment processes by proactively addressing risks and issues earlier in the lifecycle. When customers operate their businesses smoothly and stay well-prepared, we join forces to lay the foundation for lasting success and sustained trust.

A sincere thank you to SAP experts Bharath Ramamurthy, Vice President of Strategic Initiatives, Customer Support, and Kartikaye Gomber, AI Solution Architect, for their contributions to this article

entry.title: Delivering a 360° Customer View in SAP Sales Cloud V2 Using SAP CDP and Build Apps
entry.content:
Today’s sales operations extend far beyond traditional CRM data. To make accurate, timely decisions, sales teams need deeper customer intelligence such as behavioural indicators, marketing engagement metrics, transactional history, digital footprints, sentiment analysis, and segment classifications. SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP) integrates these diverse data points into a single, real-time unified profile.

This blog explains how to bring a full 360° Customer View into SAP Sales Cloud V2 using:

  • SAP CDP as the unified profile and interaction source
  • SAP Build Apps to build custom UI extensions
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 mashup capabilities to embed the experience seamlessly

 

Why a 360° Customer View Matters for Sales Reps

Traditional CRM systems give sales reps only a basic snapshot of customer information, such as:

  • Account and contact details
  • Open opportunities
  • Logged activities and visits
  • Quotes and order history

While useful, this limited view often leaves sales reps without the full context they need. In today’s competitive environment, reps must understand how customers think, behave, and engage. This requires deeper insights, including:

  • Email engagement patterns (opens, clicks, conversions)
  • Website behaviour and product interest
  • Cross-channel interaction history
  • Purchase trends and loyalty behaviours
  • Segment membership and scoring
  • Predictive signals like propensity to buy or churn risk

 

SAP CDP transforms fragmented data into a unified, real-time Golden Profile. With SAP Build Apps extending Sales Cloud V2, this intelligence flows directly to sales users at the critical moment—when they’re engaging with customers and making key decisions.

High-Level Architecture

 

 

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Enable CDP API Access

SAP CDP exposes APIs for:

  • Profiles
  • Interactions
  • Orders
  • Calculated attributes

Configure OAuth client in CDP and note:

  • Base URL
  • Client ID
  • Client Secret

 

Step 2: Configure BTP Destination

In SAP BTP:

Name: CDP

Type: HTTP

Proxy Type: Internet

URL: https://<tenant>. gigya.com

This is consumed by SAP Build Apps.

 

 

 

Step 3: Setup Integration in SAP Build Apps

Create integration for BTP destination created in last step

 

 

Create API Data Entity with following information:

Name: Specify the entity name (e.g., ‘Order History’ for this example)

Path: API Path

Capabilities: List (multiple record) or retrieve (for single record)

 

 

 

The relative path and query can be made dynamic by using a formula, as shown below:

 

 

Next, a Data Variable needs to be created to populate the UI with data based on the integration configured for the entity named ‘Order’:

 

Step 5: Create Build Apps UI

 

In this example, the UI is designed to display only the customer’s order history. The UI element is bound to the Data Variable created in the previous step.

 

 

 Build and deploy the app:

 

 Step 4: Embed Build Apps UI into SAP Sales Cloud V2

In Sales Cloud V2:

  1. Go to Extensibility → Mashups
  2. Create a URL Mashup
  3. Paste Build App deployed URL
  4. Pass context parameters:

https://<build-app-url>?customerId={displayId}

  1. Place the mashup in Account Overview tab

 

Result: True Customer 360 Experience

When the sales user opens a Account overview page:

  • They see unified CDP profile
  •  They can view every cross-channel interaction
  • They know which segments the customer belongs to
  • They get intelligent scores and signals
  • They operate inside Sales Cloud V2 with ZERO backend coding

This turns Sales Cloud into a smart, intelligence-driven selling platform.

 

Summary

By combining:

  • SAP CDP for unified customer intelligence
  • SAP Build Apps for custom UI
  • SAP Sales Cloud V2 mashups for embedding

you deliver a powerful, real-time, 360° customer view directly into the sales workflow.

entry.title: Re: Actual finish date in production order
entry.content: The behavior you’re seeing is not an error; it’s how ERP systems ensure that the actual timeline of the production order reflects the final reality once all operations are confirmed. Early confirmations are provisional; the final confirmation of all operations recalculates the order’s actual dates.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ERP - Scope Item duplicated in more than 1...
entry.content:
Hello Sandeep,

thank you for your feedback!

The leading columns in this Excel workbook are LOB and Business Area. These attributes are derived from the assignment of scope items to solution capabilities, as defined by the scope item owner.  This is not a 1:1 assignment, which is why you can find multiple rows for certain scope items.

The purpose of this structure is to enable a mapping between scope items and features in What's New and the product assistance on the basis of LOB and Business Area.

Combining LOB and Business Area into a single cell would make filtering impossible, we would lose the mapping.

If LOB and Business Area are not relevant for your use case, you can de-duplicate the records by removing the columns and using the Remove Duplicates function across the work area of the worksheet.

Kind regards
Ralf

entry.title: Re: How to avoid deleting orders
entry.content:
Why your component “disappears” from the purchase sheets is because of the following:

  • When you add a component to a work order, SAP usually creates a reservation (internal request for stock). A purchase requisition (PR) is only generated if the material is not available in stock and the order is released with the right control key/settings. If the PR is not created, the purchasing team won’t see anything in their “order sheets.”
  • If someone posts time (confirmation) before the order is released or before the PR is generated, the system may treat the component as “already consumed” against the reservation. That makes it look like the requirement has been fulfilled internally, so it doesn’t show up in purchasing.
  • The purchase department typically runs MRP (Material Requirements Planning) or checks open PRs. If your component is only sitting as a reservation and hasn’t been converted into a PR, it won’t appear in their list.
  • In PM orders, whether a component triggers a PR depends on the procurement type in the material master and the order type control key. If the control key is set to “reservation only,” purchasing won’t see it. If it is set to “external procurement,” a PR should be generated automatically once the order is released.

Perform the below steps

  • Check the order status: Make sure the work order is released before expecting the component to flow into purchasing.
  • Verify material master data: Ensure the component has the correct procurement type (e.g., F = external procurement).
  • Look at reservations vs. PRs: Use transaction codes like MB25 (reservations) and ME5A (purchase requisitions) to see where the requirement is sitting.
  • Coordinate with purchasing: They may need to run MRP or convert reservations into PRs manually depending on your setup.
  • Customizing review: You or your SAP team can adjust order type settings so that components always generate PRs when added to work orders.

entry.title: HOW TO DO SAP EWM PACKING REPACKING AND UNPACKING
entry.content:
1. Move stock from one HU to a new HU           
 2. Move stock from one HU to an existing HU          
 3. Move stock from a bin to an HU                 
4. Move stock from an HU to a bin               
 5. Move stock from a bin to a new HU 

 

***  " FOR HU TO existing HU MOVEMENT
  IF p_hu IS NOT INITIAL AND p2dest_h IS NOT INITIAL.
    CALL METHOD lo_packing->get_instance
      IMPORTING
*       es_hu_main  =                  " Structure with GLobal Fields and Indicators in Packing
        eo_instance = lo_packing. " Packing in WM with Immediately Confirmed Transfer Orders

    CALL METHOD lo_packing->init
      EXPORTING
        iv_lgnum = p_whnum "XYZ''     " Warehouse Number/Warehouse Complex
*       is_pack_controle       =                  " Structure with Fields for Packing Control
*       iv_procty              =                  " Warehouse Process Type
*       iv_execute_whr_cleanup = 'X'              " Checkbox
      EXCEPTIONS
        error    = 1                " Error, see log
        OTHERS   = 2.

entry.title: Re: Unsupported OData Version 4.01 when connecting Fiori...
entry.content:
Hello,

the Sales Order and Sales Order Simulation API using features that are added to the OData protocol with the Version 4.01 and therefore the metadata also define the version as such. The support for this version for was added at a later point in time as the purpose auf these services is not UI primarily. But of cause they can be used for that purpose.

Meanwhile, since Version 1.142 support is added, see What's new . You can get more details here: Transition to OData V4.01 

When you increase the Fiori version accordingly, you are able to resolve this issue.

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP’s Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
“Clean core” and “Artificial Intelligence” are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP’s own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP’s clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP’s “Generative AI on SAP BTP” reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term “AI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud”, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP’s stated goal of “increasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations” without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP’s standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP’s own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP’s clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP’s extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

SAP AI Core SAP S/4HANA SAP HANA Cloud SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: Re: Configuration and Submission of your UK VAT Return
entry.content:
Hi 

If you receiving this error in your Q system then the message that you have highlighted is what I am referring to.  When you are in P system and you click in Submit you are submitting your actual VAT return to HMRC.  This will be your actual VAT return for that reporting period.  

With regards to your issue about not seeing HMRC details, client secrets etc please refer the link Granting Permission to Submit the VAT Return Report Electronically.  The first time you submit your VAT return it will direct you to the HMRC portal.  Here you will prompted to enter you user and password and grant permission to SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to electronically submit your VAT report.  It is at this point where the access tokens are exchanged.  You do not get to see the client secret but they are stored.   

I hope that helps.  

Kind Regards

Sam.

entry.title: Enhancing the Power of Customer Data through the SAP BDC Partner Ecosystem
entry.content:
Enhancing the Power of Customer Data through the SAP BDC Partner Ecosystem

“There were 5 exabytes of information created between the dawn of civilization through 2003, but that much information is now created every two days.” - Eric Schmidt, former Executive Chairman at Google

The needs of enterprise have changed. CXOs are now all business strategists and not merely “department heads”. Of course, “keeping the lights on” is still very important but advances in technology, including AI, now offer up endless possibilities for efficiency gains, productivity gains and insight that can truly unleash value.

But, where is this value buried? How does one mine it? And, how does one refine the raw product into something truly valuable?

Data is the gold

The answer to the first question is easy – data is the gold! It always has been, But, now, it is being created at an exponentially larger scale than even just two decades ago, as pointed out by Eric Schmidt. The problems and challenges lie not in the data but in how to get at it, how to make sense of it.

All companies, large and small, generate so much business data compared to the recent past that basic processes have become more and more complex. When it comes to analysing this voluminous data, it can be daunting. Firstly, the sheer volume of data itself; then, there is the time consuming and thankless task of trying to “join up” data from different sources – finance data looks different to HR data which looks different to logistics data and sales data and so on.

Customer have built up tremendous reservoirs of data during their corporate lifetimes. These reservoirs only continue to grow. With the increase in data comes a requisite increase in the challenges of tapping into this great resource.

The gold miners kit list

Even in a systems landscape of a single vendor, such as SAP, these datasets from different LoB systems can present challenges when it comes to joining them together. So, what tools do we need to mine this treasure trove of data buried deep in our various systems?

Over the years, customers have invested heavily in Business Warehouses, Data Lakes and a myriad of analytics solutions. Now, with the advent and rapid advances in AI, businesses are being driven towards a promising future where, miraculously perhaps, advances in AI magically solve all of our data issues, presenting us answers with unprecedented speed and clarity.

Really? According to McKinsey’s The state of AI in 2025: Agents, innovation, and transformation, we’re not quite there yet.

Enter SAP’s Business Data Cloud (BDC). The single biggest innovation by SAP since the advent of S/4HANA.  SAP BDC brings together in one place, all of the components necessary to turn the data vision into reality. Moreover, customers who have invested in our BW systems will not see their investments wasted. Investments in BW will be able to be carried forward and connected into BDC to continue delivering the value they were designed for.

  • A fully managed software-as-a-service (SaaS) solution
  • Unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data
  • Brings together SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse
  • Partnership with Databricks adds Databricks directly into SAP Business Data Cloud

Seeing the wood for the trees

“Data is like garbage. You’d better know what you are going to do with it before you collect it.” - Mark Twain

Remember the old adage, “Garbage in, garbage out!” How so very apt in these times of AI hype – how useful can AI be if the data it relies on is garbage? How can you possibly see the wood for the trees?

SAP BDC brings together the various components needed to make sense of all of that tremendous data, regardless of volume or source, to transform the data in a way that ensures that data “garbage” is turned into data gold. Then, and only then, can AI make meaningful use of that data to deliver reliable, trustworthy and truly valuable business insight. In short, SAP BDC is a quantum leap for business data mining. It brings together the key components of data management and analysis to provide a singular toolset to power truly effective business AI.

“Please [SAP], I want some more”

The immortal words of Oliver Twist as penned by Charles Dickens, paraphrased, but just as applicable to data as to food, for hungry corporations. Would you like some more? Then, more you shall have!

SAP has a vast ecosystem of partners covering all aspects of software and services. SAP BDC gives our partners unprecedented opportunities to build innovation that drives even more impactful value for our mutual customers. The power of data unlocked by SAP BDC, combined with the incremental value enhanced by our partner offerings, will give our customers unparalleled competitive advantage.

Our strategic partners are already engaged in value-enhancing developments utilizing the power of SAP BDC, and the pipeline of partners looking to contribute via SAP BDC is growing. These use cases will enhance the customer value proposition across key business processes such as finance, customer experience, assets management and risk management. All of these partners and others with equally exciting use cases in the pipeline, will help to amplify as well as accelerate the adoption of SAP BDC.

entry.title: I have the same requirement to extend the Balance Confirmation form template. Has anyone implemented
IF_WEB_HTTP_CLIENT suppress sap_passport header
entry.content:
I am on SAP BTP ABAP Environment.

I want to make a call to a rest-api using if_web_http_client in combination with cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement and cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination

The API gives me an http code 400 with message that request has syntax errors. The call when using create_by_url is working just fine. 
I traced it back that in the call the header sap_passport gets set. The API cant handle that. There seems to be a similar problem in CPI: Solved: Suppress HTTP headers on SAP CPI HTTP adapter - SAP Community

I tried to deactive propertytype_send_sap_passport with

set_distributed_tracing_status( i_epp_status = abap_false ).

At the first two levels the attribute is set correctly, but on the third level it is set wrong as shown here in the screenshot:

So MO_HTTP_CLIENT->propertytype_send_sap_passport = 0.

MO_HTTP_CLIENT->MO_HTTP_CLIENT->propertytype_send_sap_passport = 0.

Buth then:
MO_HTTP_CLIENT->MO_HTTP_CLIENT->MO_CLIENT->propertytype_send_sap_passport = 1.

This is because when calling mo_http_client = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination with cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement in class cl_http_client in method create_by_destination the function RFC_READ_HTTP_DESTINATION is called which returns epp_enabled = abap_true and the method set_distributed_tracing_status does not override it correctly. 

Seems to me like a bug in the code?
Is there any way to customize the field epp_enabled in Communication Systems or to set the value of the property to 0?

Thanks in advande!

Here is my template code:

DATA(lt_outbound_services) = lo_ca->get_outbound_services( ).

DATA(lv_outb_serv_id) = VALUE #( lt_outbound_services[ 1 ]-id OPTIONAL ).

 

DATA(lo_dbug_desto) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_url( 'https://api.evatr.vies.bzst.de/app/v1/abfrage' ).

DATA(lo_destination) = cl_http_destination_provider=>create_by_comm_arrangement(

comm_scenario = ms_service_customizing-CommunicationScenario

comm_system_id = lo_ca->get_comm_system_id( )

service_id = lv_outb_serv_id ).

 

IF debug = abap_false.

mo_http_client = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_destination ).

ELSE.

mo_http_client = cl_web_http_client_manager=>create_by_http_destination( lo_dbug_desto ).

ENDIF.

 

mo_http_client->get_http_request( )->set_text( i_text = mv_json_http_body ).

mo_http_client->get_http_request( )->set_content_type( 'application/json' ).

mo_http_client->set_distributed_tracing_status( i_epp_status = abap_false ).

entry.title: Re: SAP CPI : How to extract SSH private key from SSH key entries in keystore?
entry.content:
@Christian_MRhere a sample script. just tried it, it works 🙂

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import com.sap.it.api.ITApiFactory;
import com.sap.it.api.keystore.KeystoreService;

def Message processData(Message message)
{
def body = new StringBuffer();
KeystoreService keyStoreService = ITApiFactory.getService(KeystoreService.class, null);

def certChain = keyStoreService.getCertificateChain("your_keypair_name");
for(int i = 0; i < certChain.size(); i++)
{
body.append("-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- ");
body.append(certChain[i].getEncoded().encodeBase64().toString().replaceAll('(.{64})','$1 '));
body.append(" -----END CERTIFICATE----- ");
}


body.append("-----BEGIN PRIVATE KEY----- ");
body.append(keyStoreService.getKeyPair("kyour_keypair_name").getPrivate().getEncoded().encodeBase64().toString().replaceAll('(.{64})','$1 '));
body.append(" -----END PRIVATE KEY-----");

message.setBody(body.toString());

return message;
}

entry.title: Re: Difference between MMBE and MB52 screens
entry.content:
MMBE shows stock by storage location, batch, special stock (consignment, project stock, etc.). It reflects real-time stock including restrictions (unrestricted, quality, blocked). It excludes certain “special stock” categories unless you drill down.

MB52 is more of a reporting transaction. It aggregates stock values by material/plant/storage location. Depending on your selection parameters, MB52 may include special stocks (like project stock, consignment, sales order stock, subcontracting stock). That is why MB52 can show more than MMBE — it’s pulling in additional categories.

For PYP, if the material is tied to a project (special stock indicator “Q”), MB52 often includes it in the totals. MMBE shows it separately under “Special Stock → Project.” If you’re only looking at unrestricted stock in MMBE, you’ll miss the project stock, but MB52 will add it into the total.

To reconcile, perform the following:

Check your MB52 selection screen. Look at the “Special Stock” indicators. If you include project stock, consignment, or sales order stock, MB52 will show higher totals. Run MB52 with filters to exclude special stocks if you want it to match MMBE.

Expand the material in MMBE and check if there’s project stock, blocked stock, or quality inspection stock. These are often the reason MB52 looks “larger.”
